$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: (Z)-Dec-1-ene-1,2-diylbis(p-tolylsiilfane)
(3a); Typical Procedure (2)-(1-Bromodec-1-en-2-yl)(p-tolyl)sulfane (1a)
(171 mg, 0.5 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of 4-toluenethiol (2a)
(70 mg, 0.75 mmol), Cu2O (7 mg, 0.05 mmol), DMEDA (8 μL, 0.075 mmol),
Cs2CO3 (326 mg, 1 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) under N2. The resulting mixture was
stirred at 120 °C for 24 h. After being cooled to r.t., the mixture was
diluted with H2O (15 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (3 × 15 mL). The
combined organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated. The crude
residue was purified by flash column chromatography (eluent: PE-EtOAc,
50:1). (Z)-[3,3-Dimethyl-1-(octylthio)but-1-en-2-yl](p-tolyl)sulfane
(3gg) Light yellow oil; yield: 166 mg (95%). Reactant: (Z)-2-Bromovinyl
sulfide 1k and Aromatic thiol 2k. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.10 (d, J
= 8.0 Hz, 2 H), 7.03 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2 H), 6.71 (s, 1 H), 2.67 (t, J =
7.2 Hz, 2 H), 2.27 (s, 3 H), 1.64-1.57 (m, 2 H), 1.37-1.26 (m, 10 H),
1.18 (s, 9 H), 0.88 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 3 H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ =
136.8, 136.1, 134.4, 132.5, 129.4, 126.5, 39.7, 33.8, 31.7, 30.5, 29.4,
29.1, 29.0, 28.5, 22.6, 20.9, 14.0. HRMS (TOF): m/z calcd for C21H34S2:
350.2102; found: 350.2104.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling of
Functionalized Aryl Bromides and Iodides with Aliphatic and Aromatic
Thiols. The appropriate quantity of stock solution A or B was added to a
4 mL vial containing the aryl bromide or iodide (1.00 mmol) and LiHMDS or
Cs2CO3 (2.4 mmol) as base, unless otherwise stated, in DME (1.5 mL). The
thiol (1.00 mmol) was then added and the vial was sealed with a cap
containing a PTFE septum. The mixture was heated at the temperature
indicated in Tables 6 and 7 until the aryl halide was consumed, as
determined by GC. Silica gel (0.5 g) was added, and the solvents were
evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel with hexane or a mixture of hexane
and ethyl acetate as eluent. Aryl sulfides were isolated in the yields
reported in Tables 6 and 7. Reactions of haloarenes bearing aromatic or
aliphatic hydroxyl groups and LiHMDS as base initially form the
corresponding sulfide with the hydroxyl group protected as the silyl
ether. However the silyl group was removed by treatment with acid (1 N
HCl) prior to the chromatographic purification. 3-Furyl octyl sulfide
(Table 6, entry 27). Colorless liquid, yield 95% 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.32
(m, 2H), 6.32 (m, 1H), 2.60 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 1.50 (quint, J = 7.3 Hz,
2H), 1.33-1.27 (m, 2H), 1.23-1.16 (m, 8H), 0.80 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H). 13C
NMR (CDCl3): δ 143.3 (2C), 116.6, 113.7, 35.4, 31.7, 29.4, 29.1, 29.0,
28.5, 22.5, 14.0. Elem. Anal. Calcd for C12H2OOS: C, 67.87; H, 9.49.
Found: C, 67.83; H, 9.31.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM silica gel used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A General, Efficient, and Functional-Group-Tolerant Catalyst System for
the Palladium-Catalyzed Thioetherification of Aryl Bromides and Iodides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Fernandez-Rodriguez, Manuel A.; Hartwig, John F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74(4), 1663-1672

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-154-CAS-2903936
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 534-17-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7681-65-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 872-50-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: A General procedure for decarboxylative C?S
coupling. To a solution of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) (3 mL) charged
with phenylpropiolic acid (0.5 mmol) and thiol (0.75 mmol) was added CuI
(3.8 mg, 0.02 mmol) and Cs2CO3 (391 mg, 1.2 mmol). The resulting mixture
was stirred at 90 °C. Upon completion of the reaction (approx. 24 hr),
the mixture was cooled to room temperature, poured into a solution of HCl
in water (1 N, 15 mL), and extracted several times with 15 mL of ethyl
acetate. The combined organic layers were washed with water and brine,
dried over Na2SO4, and filtered. The solvent was removed in vacuo and the
residue was purified by column chromatography (silica gel, eluent:
hexane/ethyl acetate) to afford the coupling product.
(4-Chlorostyryl)(octyl)sulfane (3ae, Z/E = 51:49). Obtained as a yellow
liquid in 95% yield. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.44-7.17 (m, 4H), 6.71(d,
0.49 × 1H), 6.42-6.36 (m, 1H), 6.27 (d, 0.51 × 1H), 2.79 (t, 2H),
1.69(quint, 2H), 1.41-1.28 (m, 10H), 0.89 (t, 3H); 13C NMR (75 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 135.7, 135.5, 132.2, 132.0, 129.8, 128.7, 128.6, 128.3, 126.6,
126.4, 125.1, 124.0, 35.9, 32.6, 31.8, 30.2, 29.4, 29.1, 28.8, 28.5,
22.6, 14.1; HR EIMS: 282.1210 m/z (calcd. for C16H23ClS: 282.1209).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Method B1: The sulfamidate (1.00 eq.), DBU
(1.05 eq.) and S-nucleophile (1.10 eq.) were heated in DMF at 50 °C for 1
h, when consumption of sulfamidate was observed by TLC and/or GC-MS. The
solution was then cooled, the solvent removed and the residue solved into
a mixture of aqueous 10% H2SO4/CH2Cl2 (1:1) and stirred for 8 h at room
temperature to hydrolize the sulfamic acid intermediate. In all methods,
the aqueous layer was successively extracted with ethyl acetate (2×20
mL), dried over Na2SO4, concentrated and the crude product
chromatographed (hexane/ethyl acetate, 7:3) to give the desired SN2
products.
(S)-2-(Methoxycarbonylaminomethyl)-N-methoxy-N-methyl-2-(octylthio)propanamide.
(S)-10. Colorless oil; yield: 95%. [α]25D = –1.7 (c 1.08, CHCl3); 1H NMR
(CDCl3): δ 0.83 (t, 3H, J=6.6 Hz, CH2CH3), 1.10-1.38 (m, 10H, (CH2)5CH3),
1.41-1.57 (m, 5H, CCH3 + SCH2CH2), 2.40 (td, 1H, J=7.3 Hz, J=11.6 Hz,
SCH2), 2.54 (td, 1H, J=7.4 Hz, J=11.6 Hz, SCH2), 3.21 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.51
(dd, 1H, J=8.4 Hz, J=13.6 Hz, CH2N), 3.58-3.69 (m, 4H, OCH3 + CH2N), 3.72
(s, 3H, OCH3), 5.29 (br dd, 1H, J=4.9 Hz, J=7.2 Hz, NH); 13C NMR (CDCl3):
δ 14.0 (CH2CCH3, 20.3 (CCCH3), 22.5 (CH2CH3), 28.9, 29.0, 29.3, 29.6
(SCH2CH2CH2CH2CH2CH2), 31.7 (SCH2CH2), 34.1 (NCH3), 49.0 (CH2N), 51.4
(CCH3), 52.0 (OCH3), 60.6 (OCH3), 157.3 (NCO2), 172.7 (CON); ESI+(m/z ) =
349.5. Anal. calcd. for C16H32N2O4S: C, 55.14; H, 9.26; N, 8.04; S, 9.20.
Found: C, 55.29; H, 9.31; N, 8.13; S, 9.16.

$DATUM 108-88-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure for the cross coupling of
aryl bromides and thiols. To a solution of Pd2(dba)3 (9.2 mg, 0.010 mmol)
and DPPF (11.1 mg, 0.020 mmol) in toluene (1.0 ml) were added
bromobenzene (0.11 ml, 1.0 mmol), iPr2NEt (0.19 ml, 1.1 mmol) and
Octanethiol (0.17 ml, 1.0 mmol) at room temperature. After the solution
was stirred under reflux for 3 h, the mixture was cooled to room
temperature. The reaction was then quenched by addition of water. The
mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (10 mL x 3), and the combined
organic layers were washed with brine, dried over dry Na2SO4, and
filterd. The filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified
by flash column chromatography on silica gel to afford Octyl 3-thienyl
sulfide as a colorless oil, yield 95%. 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ 7.31 (q, J = 5.0
Hz and 3.0 Hz, 1H), 7.11 (dd, J = 3.0 Hz and 1.3 Hz, 1H), 7.02 (dd, J =
5.0 Hz and 1.3 Hz, 1H), 2.84 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.61 (quint, J = 7.5
Hz, 2H), 1.40 (quint, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 1.31-1.26 (m, 8H), 0.88 (t, J =
7.0 Hz, 3H); 13C NMR (CDCl3) δ 132.3, 129.4, 125.7, 122.5, 35.0, 31.7,
29.2, 29.0, 29.0, 28.6, 22.5, 14.0; IR (neat) 2960, 2926, 2852, 1637,
1460, 1377, 1350, 1300, 1263, 1196, 1097, 895, 852, 775 cm-1; MS (EI):
m/z = 228 (M+); HRMS (EI) calcd for C12H20S2 (M+) 228.1006, found
228.1000.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Facile preparation of aryl sulfides using palladium catalysis under mild
conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Okauchi, Tatsuo; Kuramoto, Kouji; Kitamura, Mitsuru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synlett (2010), (19), 2891-2894

$DATUM 7681-65-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure A for the Synthesis of Aryl,
Alkyl, and Vinyl Sulfides (Tables 3 and 5-10). An oven-dried round-bottom
flask containing a magnetic stir bar was sealed with a rubber septum and
then evacuated and backfilled with argon (the sequence was repeated three
times) with cooling to rt. The round-bottom flask was then charged with
anhydrous potassium phosphate (1.5 equiv), copper(I) iodide (10 mol %),
cis-1,2-cyclohexanediol (20 mol %), and dry DMF (2 mL). The solution
which resulted was stirred for 5-10 min at rt. The reaction mixture
turned a light green color within 3-5 min. The reaction vessel was
evacuated and backfilled with argon one more time before adding the thiol
and the aryl, alkyl, or vinyl iodide. This operation was done to prevent
the formation of disulfides in the presence of oxygen inside the reaction
vessel. The appropriate thiol (1.2 equiv) was added to the reaction
mixture through a rubber septum and the mixture stirred for another 5 min
at rt. The aryl or alkyl or vinyl iodide or bromide (1.0 equiv) of choice
was dissolved in a minimum amount of dry DMFand was added to the
resulting reaction mixture through a rubber septum. The contents of the
reaction mixture were allowed to stir at 30-110 °C for 0.5-15 h depending
on the substrate. The reaction mixture was then cooled to rt and filtered
through a pad of silica gel to remove insoluble residues. The pad of
silica gel was washed ethyl acetate (100 mL). The combined filtrate was
washed with brine (4 x 50 mL), dried (Na2SO4), and concentrated in vacuo
on a rotatory evaporator. The concentrated crude oil was purified by
flash column chromatography on silica gel using the eluent (2-10%) ethyl
acetate and hexane (depending on the substrate) to obtain the pure
product (75-98% yields). 3-[(2-Methylbutyl) sulfanylpyridine (89) (Table
8, entry 22). The general procedure (A) was followed (8 h). The
3-Iodopyridine (100 mg, 0.49 mmol), 2-methyl-1-butanethiol (61.5 mg, 0.59
mmol), CuI (9.3 mg, 0.049 mmol), 1,2-cis-cyclohexanediol (11.4 mg, 0.098
mmol), K3PO4 (156 mg, 0.74 mmol) and DMF (2.0 mL) were stirred at 80 °C
to obtain the thioether 89 (84 mg, 95% yield) as a colorless oil. Column
chromatography solvent (3-5% EtOAc in hexane) provided pure 89. 1H NMR
(300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.59 (1H, s), δ 8.42 (1H, s), δ 7.64 (1H, d, J = 8.0
Hz), δ 7.23-7.19 (1H, m), δ 2.99-2.93 (1H, m), δ 2.81-2.74(1H, m), δ
1.69-1.49 (2H, m), δ 1.33-1.24 (1H, m), δ 1.03 (3H, d, J = 6.6 Hz), δ
0.91 (3H, t, J = 7.4 Hz). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 149.9, 146.7, 136.4,
123.4, 40.8, 34.5, 28.6, 18.7, 11.1. HRMS (ESI) (M + H)+, Calcd. for
C10H16NS 182.1003; Found 182.1004.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A very active Cu-catalytic system for the synthesis of aryl, heteroaryl,
and vinyl sulfides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Preparation of Ethyl
Alkyl/Aryl Dithiocarbamate Derivatives (7). A solution of the different
aliphatic isothiocyanates (6) (26.0 mmol) was reacted with 3.3 mL (39.0
mmol) of ethanethiol in the presence of Et3N (0.3 mL, 26.0 mmol) in 40 mL
of dry THF and was refluxed for 20 h to form 7 in about 95% yields. In
the case of aromatic dithiocarbamates the reaction was carried out under
the same conditions with toluene as a solvent and in the presence of
catalytic amount of dibutyltin dilaurate. In both cases, evaporation of
the solvent followed by flash chromatography yielded the desired product.
Ethyl cyclohexyldithiocarbamate (7g) 7 was prepared as described in the
general procedure, in 95% yield: 5.0 g, colorless oil. 1H NMR 7.90 and
7.01 (1 H, s), 4.47 – 4.31 and 3.79 - 3.70 (1 H, m), 3.28 - 3.18 (2 H,
m), 2.07 – 2.00 (2 H, m), 1.75 - 1.66 (3 H, m), 1.37 – 1.16 ppm (8 H, m);
13C NMR 199.3 and 196.3, 55.5, 32.3, 31.7, 29.4, 25.3, 24.7, 14.2 ppm.

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Using an established procedure 1 a solution of
carboxylic acid (5 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (25 mL) was treated with isobutyl
chloroformate (816 mg, 6.0 mmol) and Et3N (505 mg, 5 mmol). After
stirring for 30 minutes at room temperature, 1-dodecanethiol (1.11 g, 5.5
mmol), Et3N (505 mg, 1.0 equiv.), and DMAP (31 mg, 0.25 mmol) were added
successively and the resulting mixture stirred for 70 minutes at room
temperature. The reaction was quenched by addition of H2O (25 mL) and
extracted with ethyl acetate (2 × 50 mL). Combined organic phase was
washed with brine and dried with MgSO4. Purification by flash column
chromatography on silica gel or recrystallizations in hexanes or
EtOAc/hexanes (2 : 98 v/v). S-Dodecyl
(S)-2-(((benzyloxy)carbonyl)amino)-3-phenylpropanethioate (1a)3 .
Following the general procedure A and purification by column
chromatography over silica gel column (CHCl3/hexanes, 1:1 v/v). S-Dodecyl
4-oxopentanethioate (1p). Following the general procedure A and
purification by column chromatography over silica gel column (1:9 v/v
EtOAc : hexanes,) gave the title compound 1p as a semi white solid (2.85
g, 95%). Rf 0.53 (1:4, v/v EtOAc : hexanes); Mp 33-34 °C. 1H-NMR (400
MHz, CDCl3) δ 2.88-2.82 (m, 4H), 2.79-2.75 (m, 2H), 2.18 (s, 3H),
1.58-1.51 (m, 2H), 1.40-1.16 (m, 18H), 0.88 (t, J= 6.9 Hz, 3H); 13C-NMR
(101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 205.9, 198.3, 38.0, 37.4, 31.8, 29.7, 29.5(3),
29.5(2), 29.4(7), 29.4, 29.8, 29.2, 29.0, 28.8, 28.7, 22.6, 14.0; IR νmax
2931, 2922, 2853, 1720, 1686, 1366, 1162, 1071, 989; HRMS Found (M + Na)+
323.2020, C17H32O2S requires (M + Na)+ 323.2021.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure:
(1S*,2R*)-N-Butyl-2-(phenylthio)cyclopropanecarboxamide (17ff): Typical
Procedure III: An oven-dried, 10-mL Weaton vial was charged with
bromocyclopropane 12f (110 mg, 0.5 mmol, 1 equiv), 18-crown-6 (13.2 mg,
0.05 mmol, 10 mol %), KOH (98 mg, 1.75 mmol, 3.5 equiv), thiophenol (110
mg, 1 mmol, 2 equiv), and anhydrous THF (5 mL). The mixture was stirred
at 85 °C for 12 h. The crude mixture was filtered through a fritted
funnel and the filtrate was concentrated under vacuum. The residual crude
material, containing a mixture of diastereomeric cyclopropylsulfides
(trans:cis = 2:1) was combined with potassium tert-butoxide (168 mg, 1.50
mmol, 3.0 equiv) in a 10-mL Weaton vial, then the mixture was dissolved
in dry THF (total volume of 8 mL) and heated at 85 °C for 6 h. The
resulting mixture was filtered through a fritted funnel into an
evaporating flask, and the filtrate was concentrated under vacuum. The
residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel to
obtain the individual trans-isomer of the title compound.
(1S*,2R*)-N-Butyl-2-(dodecylthio)cyclopropanecarboxamide (17fa): The
reaction was performed according to typical procedure III, employing
bromocyclopropane 12f (110 mg, 0.50 mmol) and dodeca-nethiol (202 mg,
1.00 mmol) to produce the title compound. A white solid, Yield 162 mg
(0.48 mmol, 95%). Initial dr 1:1, after equilibration was upgraded to
16:1. mp 50- 52 °C, Rf 0.23 (eluent hexane/EtOAc 3:1). 1H NMR (500.13
MHz, CDCl3) δ 5.84 (br s, 1H), 3.32- 3.22 (m, 2H), 2.64- 2.52 (m, 2H),
2.45- 2.36 (m, 1H), 1.69- 1.56 (m, 2H), 1.55- 1.44 (m, 4H), 1.42- 1.33
(m, 4H), 1.44- 1.20 (m, 16H), 1.02- 0.96 (m, 1H), 0.94 (t, J = 7.4 Hz,
3H), 0.89 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 3H); 13C NMR (125.76 MHz, CDCl3) δ 171.1, 39.5
( - ), 33.4 (- ), 31.9 (- ), 31.7 ( - ), 29.62 (- ), 29.60 ( - ), 29.58 (
- ), 29.57 (- ), 29.5 ( - ), 29.3 (- ), 29.2 ( -), 28.8 ( - ), 25.9 (+ ),
22.6 (- ), 21.4 (+ ), 20.0 ( -), 16.3 ( - ), 14.1 ( + ), 13.7 ( + ); IR
(KBr, cm-1 ) 3271, 2955, 2918, 2849, 1636, 1558, 1456, 1277, 1232, 746,
719, 658, 501, 403; HRMS (TOF ES) found 342.2833, calcd for C20H40NOS (M
+ H) 342.2831 (0.6 ppm).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM With water-soluble carbodiimide (WSCD): To a solution of acid (1; 1.05 g,
5.83 mmol), WSCD (1.34 g, 6.99 mmol), and DMAP (36.0 mg, 0.292 mmol) in
CH2Cl2 (23 mL) was added 1-dodecanethiol (1.67 mL, 6.99 mmol). The
solution was stirred for 40 min at r.t., and the reaction was quenched by
addition of H2O (50 mL). A similar purification procedure as above
afforded the thiol ester 3. 3-(4-Methoxyphenyl)-thiopropionic Acid
(S)-dodecyl Ester (3). Yield (2.01 g, 5.51mmol, 95%). mp: 31-32 °C. IR
(film): 2925, 2853, 1693, 1612, 1514, 1465, 1248, 1178, 1040, 823 cm-1.
1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.10 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2 H), 6.82 (d, J = 8.8
Hz, 2 H), 3.78 (s, 3 H), 2.94-2.79 (m, 6 H), 1.58-1.51 (m, 2 H), 1.25
(br, 18 H), 0.88 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 3 H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ =
198.8, 158.2, 132.3, 132.3, 129.3, 129.3, 113.9, 55.2, 45.8, 31.9, 30.7,
29.6, 29.6, 29.5, 29.5, 29.3, 29.1, 28.9, 28.8, 22.7, 14.1. Anal. Calcd
for C22H36O2S: C, 72.48; H, 9.95. Found: C, 72.38; H, 9.67. (b).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Cesium-Mediated Addition of Thiol to Alkyne: A
Typical Procedure. The reaction of dodecanethiol with phenylacetylene is
representative (Table 1, entry 10). Cesium carbonate (0.016 g, 0.050
mmol) was placed in a 20-mL reaction flask under argon. Dimethyl
sulfoxide (3.0 mL) and dodecanethiol (0.12 g, 0.60 mmol) were added at
room tem-perature. After the mixture was stirred for 15 min, 2,2,6,6-
tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl (0.016 g, 0.10 mmol) was added. The whole
mixture was stirred for 15 min. Finally, phenylacetylene (0.051 g, 0.50
mmol) was added and the resulting mixture was stirred for 4 h. Water (10
mL) was added, and the product was extracted with hexane/ethyl acetate
(40:1, 3 x 10 mL). The combined organic layer was dried over sodium
sulfate and concentrated under reduced pressure. Silica gel column
purification of the crude oil provided 0.13 g of dodecyl styryl sulfide
(1a, 0.43 mmol, E/Z ) 7:93) in 86% yield.
2-Dodecylthio-3-phenyl-2-propenyl methyl ether (1r, E/Z ) 17:83): IR
(neat) 2924, 2853, 2820, 1599, 1491, 1445, 1192, 1117, 1084, 1032, 914,
847, 752, 694 cm-1; 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ 0.88 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H), 1.18-1.40
(m, 18H), 1.56 (tt, J = 7.5, 7.5 Hz, 2H), 2.81 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 0.83 x
2H), 2.83 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 0.17 x 2H), 3.39 (s, 0.17 x 3H), 3.41 (s, 0.83
x3H), 4.17 (s, 0.17 x 2H), 4.20 (s, 0.83 x 2H), 6.49 (s, 0.17 x 1H), 6.73
(s, 0.83 x 1H), 7.15-7.38 (m, 3H), 7.60 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H); 13C NMR
(CDCl3) for major isomer δ 14.1, 22.7, 28.8, 29.2, 29.3, 29.5, 29.55,
29.58, 29.61, 29.62, 29.9, 31.9, 57.5, 76.4, 127.1, 128.0, 129.4, 129.7,
132.9, 136.3. Found: C, 75.74; H, 10.18. Calcd for C22H36OS: C, 75.80; H,
10.41.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective, E:Z 17:83
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Stereoselective Hydrothiolation of Alkynes Catalyzed by Cesium Base:
Facile Access to (Z)-1-Alkenyl Sulfides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DATUM Ethyl [Methyl (5-Acetamido-4,7,8,9-tetra-O-acetyl-3,5-dideoxy-D-glycero-α
-D-galacto-non-2-ulopyranosyl)onate]-(2 → 3)-2,4,6-tri-O-acetyl-1-thio-β
-D-galactopyranoside (7) Method (a) To a solution of 4 (305 mg, 0.37
mmol) and EtSH (0.55 mL, 7.5 mmol) in abs CH2Cl2 (12 mL) was added
BF3·Et2O (0.23 mL, 1.88 mmol) dropwise with stirring at 0 °C. After being
stirred for 7 h at r.t., the reaction mixture was transferred dropwise,
through a cannula by argon flow, into an Erlenmeyer flask containing an
ice-cold, vigorously stirred aq solution (200 mL) of NaHCO3 (13 g). The
mixture was extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 × 50 mL), the combined extracts were
dried and concentrated. Column chromatography (toluene → toluene-EtOH,
7:1) of the residue gave 7. White foam, yield 262 mg. 86%. Rf = 0.2
(toluene-EtOH, 10:1); [α]D20 -5° (c 1, CH2Cl2). 1H NMR: δ = 1.29 (t, 3 H,
J = 7.2 Hz, SCH2CH3), 1.72 (t, 1 H, J3ax,4 = 12.4 Hz, H-3ax NeuAc),
1.86-2.23 (8 s, 24 H, 8 CH3CO), 2.60 (dd, 1 H, J3eq,4 = 4.7, J3eq,3ax =
12.8 Hz, H-3eq NeuAc), 2.74 (m, 2 H, SCH2CH3), 3.65 (dd, 1 H, J6,5 = 10.7
Hz, J6,7 = 2.6 Hz, H- 6 NeuAc), 3.86 (s 3 H, CH3O), 3.89 (t, 1 H, J5,6 =
6.3 Hz, H-5 Gal), 4.02 (m, 4 H, H-5, H-9 NeuAc, 2 H-6 Gal), 4.16 (dd, 1
H, J9',8 = 2.7 Hz, J9,9' = 12.4 Hz, H-9' NeuAc), 4.60 (dd, 1 H, J3,4 =
3.4 Hz, H-3 Gal), 4.63 (d, 1 H, J1,2 = 9.7 Hz, H-1 Gal), 4.88 (m, 1 H,
J4,5 = 10.5 Hz, H-4 NeuAc), 4.95 (d, 1 H, H-4 Gal), 5.06 (t, 1 H, J2,3 =
9.7 Hz, H-2 Gal), 5.27 (d, 1 H, JNH,5 = 10.0 Hz, NH), 5.37 (dd, 1 H, J7,8
= 9.0 Hz, H-7 NeuAc), 5.53 (m, 1 H, J8,9 = 5.5 Hz, H-8 NeuAc). 13C NMR: δ
= 14.9 (SCH2CH3), 20.7, 20.9, 21.4 (CH3CO), 24.3 (SCH2CH3), 37.6 (C-3
NeuAc), 49.2 (C-5 NeuAc), 53.1 (CH3O), 62.2 (C-6 Gal), 62.4 (C-9 NeuAc),

NeuAc), 72.1 (C-6 NeuAc), 72.3 (C-3 Gal), 74.3 (C-5 Gal), 83.6 (C-1 Gal),

C, 49.92; H, 6.10; N, 1.65.

$DATUM 2-Allylsulfanyl oxolane. To a solution of 2,3 dihydrofuran (1.51 mL, 20
mmol) and pyridinium -p-toluenesulfonate (354 mg, 1.33 mmol) in CH2Cl2
(50 mL) was added allyl mercaptan (1.06 mL, 13.33 mmol). The mixture was
stirred at room temperature for 8 hours, and was hydrolyzed with
saturated NaCl and extracted with CH2Cl2. The combined organic extracts
were dried (MgSO4), filtered and concentrated. Purification by flash
column chromatography (hexane/ether 6/4) provided 1.63 g (95% yield) of
the desired product. 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ 5.87-5.76 (m, 1H), 5.29 (dd, J =
3.6, 7.5 Hz, 1H), 5.16-5.04 (m, 2H), 3.91-3.84 (m, 2H), 3.30 (dd, J =
1.2, 8.5 Hz, 1H), 3.11 (dd, J = 1.2, 5.8 Hz, 1H), 2.25-2.20 (m, 1H),
1.97-1.93 (m, 1H), 1.85-1.78 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (CDCl3) δ 134.4, 116.7,
83.0, 66.8, 33.8, 32.2, 24.9; IR (neat, cm-1) 2976, 1049, 913; MS
(DCI/NH3) m/z (MNH4+) = 162.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2-thioetherbenzaldehyde general procedure
2-nitrobenzaldehyde (33 mmol) and K2CO3 (37 mmol) were dissolved in dry
DMF (50 ml) under a nitrogen atmosphere. The thiol (35 mmol) was then
added at room temp, while stirring at a suitable rate to control the
exothermic reaction and the mixture was stirred at 80°C for 16 hour. The
mixture was cooled at room temp., H2O (200 ml) was added and the mixture
was extracted with MTBE/pentane (1:1). The organic layers were washed
with aq. sat. NH4Cl solution and brine, dried with MgSO4, and the
solvents were distilled under reduced pressure. The crude product was
purified by bulb-to-bulb distillation or column chromatography
(Silicagel, Pent/Et2O). 2-(tert-butylthio)-5-nitrobenzaldehyde 95% yield.
1H NMR (400 MHz, CD2Cl2): δ 10.69 (s, 1H), 8.70 (d, JHH = 2.7 Hz, 1H),
8.33 (dd, JHH = 8.5, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.84 (d, JHH = 8.5 Hz, 1H), 1.38 (s,
9H); 13C NMR 100 MHz, CD2Cl2): δ 191.3 (CH), 148.7 (C), 145.1 (C), 140.6
(CH), 140.4 (C), 127.2 (CH), 123.4 (CH), 49.8 (C), 31.2 (CH3).

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Reaction of
Compounds 12-15, 20, and 24a-d with Ethanthiol/KSCN (Procedure D). A
solution of compounds 12-15, 20, 24a-d (0.5 mmol), ethanthiol/KSCN (0.6
mmol), K2CO3 (0.6 mmol) in dry CH3CN (10 mL) was stirred at room
temperature. On completion of reaction (3-4 h, TLC monitoring), the
reaction mixture was filtered and filtrate was concentrated under vacuum.
The crude residue obtained was purified by column chromatography using
hexane and ethyl acetate (3:1) to give pure compounds 2a, 2b, 3a-h, and
4a-h.
(2R*,3S*,4R*,6S*)-6-((Ethylthio)methyl)tetrahydro-2,3,4-triphenyl-2H-pyran-4-ol
(4a). By use of procedureD, the reaction of 24a with ethanthiol gave 4a
in 95% yield as a colorless viscous oil. UV (EtOH): λmax (ε) 219 (13890).
IR (CHCl3, cm-1): 3467 (OH). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 1.10 (t, J= 7.5
Hz, 3H, CH3), 1.92-2.13 (m, 3H, 2H of C-5 + 1H of OH), 2.41-2.46 (m, 2H,
S-CH2), 2.56-2.58 (m, 1H, CH2S) 2.67-2.74 (m, 1H,CH2S), 3.11 (d, J=9.9Hz,
1H,CH),4.25-4.34 (m, 1H,CH), 5.12 (d, J=10.5 Hz, 1H, CH), 6.78-6.99 (m,
5H, ArH), 7.01-7.11 (m, 10H, ArH). 13C NMR (normal/DEPT-135, CDCl3): δ
14.8 (+ve, CH3), 27.1 (-ve, S-CH2), 36.9 (-ve, CH2-S), 44.3 (-ve, CH),
58.1 (+ve, CH), 73.6 (+ve, CH), 75.1 (ab, C-4), 78.9 (+ve, CH), 124.5
(+ve, ArCH), 126.7 (+ve, ArCH), 126.8 (+ve, ArCH), 127.8 (+ve, ArCH),
128.0 (+ve, ArCH), 128.9 (+ve, ArCH), 129.8 (+ve, ArCH), 132.9 (+ve,
ArCH), 136.1 (ab, ArC), 139.3 (ab, ArC). FAB-MS m/z 404 [M + ]. Anal.
(C26H28O2S) C, H, S.

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Reaction of
Compounds 12-15, 20, and 24a-d with Ethanthiol/KSCN (Procedure D). A
solution of compounds 12-15, 20, 24a-d (0.5 mmol), ethanthiol/KSCN (0.6
mmol), K2CO3 (0.6 mmol) in dry CH3CN (10 mL) was stirred at room
temperature. On completion of reaction (3-4 h, TLC monitoring), the
reaction mixture was filtered and filtrate was concentrated under vacuum.
The crude residue obtained was purified by column chromatography using
hexane and ethyl acetate (3:1) to give pure compounds 2a, 2b, 3a-h, and
4a-h.
(2R*,3S*,4R*,6S*)-2-(4-Chlorophenyl)-6-((ethylthio)methyl)-tetrahydro-3,4-diphenyl-2H-pyran-4-ol
(4e). By use of procedure D, the reaction of 24c with ethanthiol gave 4e
in 95% yield as a colorless viscous oil. UV (EtOH): λmax (ε) 222 (20410).
IR (CHCl3, cm-1): 3498 (OH). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 1.14 (t, J=7.5
Hz, 3H,CH3), 1.99-2.18 (m, 3H,2H of C-5+1H of OH), 2.49-2.60 (m, 3H, 2H
of S-CH2 +1H of CH2S), 2.63-2.78 (m, 1H, CH2S), 3.15 (d, J= 10.8 Hz, 1H,
CH), 4.32-4.40 (m, 1H, CH), 5.17 (d, J= 10.5 Hz, 1H, CH), 6.71-7.16 (m,
14H, ArH). 13C NMR (normal/DEPT-135, CDCl3): δ 14.8 (+ve, CH3), 27.1
(-ve, S-CH2), 36.8 (-ve, CH2-S), 44.2 (-ve, CH2), 58.1 (+ve, CH), 73.5
(+ve, CH), 75.0 (ab, C-4), 78.9 (+ve, CH), 124.5 (+ve, ArCH), 126.6 (+ve,
ArCH), 126.7 (+ve, ArCH), 127.7 (+ve, ArCH), 127.9 (+ve, ArCH), 128.1
(+ve, ArCH), 128.8 (+ve, ArCH), 129.7 (+ve, ArCH), 132.8 (ab, ArC), 136.1
(ab, ArC), 139.3 (ab, ArC), 145.8 (ab, ArC).FAB-MS m/z 438 [M + ] (75%),
440 [M + ] (24%). Anal. (C26H27ClO2S) C, H, S.

$DATUM 67-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Experimental Procedure. Thiol (7.56
mmol) was taken in dry DMSO (25 ml) and gaseous CO2 was bubbled through
it for 30 min at room temperature. To this, a mixture of
triphenylphosphine (7.56 mmol) and diethyl azodicarboxylate (7.56 mmol)
was added slowly in 2-3 small portions. Next, the corresponding thiol
(7.56 mmol) was added with constant stirring at rt. The reaction
continued until completion (cf Table 1) as confirmed by TLC. The reaction
mixture was then poured into distilled water (50 ml) and extracted with
ethyl acetate thrice. The organic layer was separated and dried over
anhydrous sodium sulphate and then concentrated to afford the desired
S,S-dialkyl dithiocarbonate. Entry: 17; Time (h): 2; Yield (%): 95.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM chemoselective, Mitsunobu reaction, mechanism studied, alternatively
reaction carried out using DMF, benzene, acetonitrile, dichloromethane,
hexane, heptane, methanol, chloroform and acetone as solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A high yielding, one-pot synthesis of S,S-dialkyl dithiocarbonates
through the corresponding thiols using Mitsunobu's reagent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Chaturvedi, A. K.; Chaturvedi, D.; Mishra, N.; Mishra, V.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the Iranian Chemical Society (2010), 7(3), 702-706

$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM B.
(S)-4-((4-chlorophenoxy)methyl)-1-(4-(3-(ethylthio)-2-hydroxypropoxy)-3-methoxyphenyl)pyridin-2(1H)-one
To a solution of ethanethiol (0.08 mL, 1.04 mmol) in 25% aqueous KOH (233
mg, 1.04 mmol) was added
(R)-4-((4-chlorophenoxy)methyl)-1-(3-methoxy-4-(oxiran-2-ylmethoxy)phenyl)pyridin-2(1H)-one
Part A (43 mg, 0.104 mmol) in THF (2 mL). Tetrabutylammonium bromide (3.3
mg, 10.4 μmol) was added and the mixture was stirred overnight. The
mixture was diluted with water and extracted with EtOAc. The combined
organic extracts were washed with water, dried (MgSO4), concentrated and
the residue was purified by Chromatography (SiO2 solvent gradient 33-60%
EtOAc/Hexanes) to give thioether 10B (47 mg, 95 % yield) as a white
solid.
(S)-4-((4-chlorophenoxy)methyl)-1-(4-(3-(ethylthio)-2-hydroxypropoxy)-3-methoxyphenyl)pyridin-2(1H)-one,
yield (47 mg, 95 %). LC-MS, [M + H]+ = 476.

(MCHR1) antagonists

A.; Ngu, Khehyong; Wang, Zhenghua

$DATUM 7681-65-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure A for the Synthesis of Aryl,
Alkyl, and Vinyl Sulfides (Tables 3 and 5-10). An oven-dried round-bottom
flask containing a magnetic stir bar was sealed with a rubber septum and
then evacuated and backfilled with argon (the sequence was repeated three
times) with cooling to rt. The round-bottom flask was then charged with
anhydrous potassium phosphate (1.5 equiv), copper(I) iodide (10 mol %),
cis-1,2-cyclohexanediol (20 mol %), and dry DMF (2 mL). The solution
which resulted was stirred for 5-10 min at rt. The reaction mixture
turned a light green color within 3-5 min. The reaction vessel was
evacuated and backfilled with argon one more time before adding the thiol
and the aryl, alkyl, or vinyl iodide. This operation was done to prevent
the formation of disulfides in the presence of oxygen inside the reaction
vessel. The appropriate thiol (1.2 equiv) was added to the reaction
mixture through a rubber septum and the mixture stirred for another 5 min
at rt. The aryl or alkyl or vinyl iodide or bromide (1.0 equiv) of choice
was dissolved in a minimum amount of dry DMFand was added to the
resulting reaction mixture through a rubber septum. The contents of the
reaction mixture were allowed to stir at 30-110 °C for 0.5-15 h depending
on the substrate. The reaction mixture was then cooled to rt and filtered
through a pad of silica gel to remove insoluble residues. The pad of
silica gel was washed ethyl acetate (100 mL). The combined filtrate was
washed with brine (4 x 50 mL), dried (Na2SO4), and concentrated in vacuo
on a rotatory evaporator. The concentrated crude oil was purified by
flash column chromatography on silica gel using the eluent (2-10%) ethyl
acetate and hexane (depending on the substrate) to obtain the pure
product (75-98% yields). tert-Butyl 4-acetophenyl sulfide (82) (Table 8,
entry 15).5 The general procedure (A) was followed (6 h). The
1-(4-Iodophenyl)ethanone (100 mg, 0.41 mmol), tert-butyl hydrosulfide
(44.2 mg, 0.49 mmol), CuI (7.8 mg, 0.041 mmol), 1,2-cis-cyclohexanediol
(9.5 mg, 0.082 mmol), K3PO4 (130 mg, 0.61 mmol) and DMF (2.0 mL) were
stirred at 60-70 °C to obtain the thioether 82 (81 mg, 95% yield) as a
colorless oil. Column chromatography solvent (10% EtOAc in hexane)
provided pure 82. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.91 (2H, d, J = 8.5 Hz), δ
7.63 (2H, d, J = 8.5 Hz), δ 2.63 (3H, s), δ 1.33 (9H, s). 13C NMR (75
MHz, CDCl3): δ 139.3, 137.8, 136.7, 129.6, 128.1, 46.7, 31.0, 26.5.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A very active Cu-catalytic system for the synthesis of aryl, heteroaryl,
and vinyl sulfides

$DATUM 1314-56-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: S,S-Thioacetalization of carbonyl compounds
(general procedure): A mixture of carbonyl compounds (2 mmol), dithiol
(2.2 mmol) or thiol (4.4 mmol) and P2O5/SiO2 (5 mg) was stirred at
ambient temperature. After completion of reaction as checked by TLC, it
was diluted with n-hexane and the catalyst was filtered off. The filtrate
solution (50 ml) was washed with aqueous 10% NaOH (2 x 10 ml) solution
and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated by
rotary evaporator and the crude product was purified through a column of
silica gel (n-hexane:EtOAc, 80:20) to obtain the pure product. Entry 32d,
yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, silica support used, reusable catalyst, no
solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Silica gel-supported phosphorus pentoxide: a reusable catalyst for
S,S-acetalization of carbonyl groups under ambient conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Shaterian, Hamid Reza; Azizi, Kobra; Fahimi, Nafiseh
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Sulfur Chemistry (2011), 32(1), 85-91

$DATUM 4

$DATUM 95

$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0

$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. B01C04E23, yield 95%. MW: 491.66
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME433 STEP1
$RXN

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.

$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. B01C04E30, yield 95%. MW: 461.59
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number

$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME437 STEP1

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 80472-30-6
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 135822-88-7
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 513-53-1
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 951335-89-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16090198
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.

$DATUM 951636-86-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16081708
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.

5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. B01C06E21, yield 95%. MW: 491.62
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2

$DATUM 14338-32-0

$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. B01C06E23, yield 95%. MW: 505.65
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. B01C06E30, yield 95%. MW: 475.58
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.

of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3

modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of

respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN

$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME448 STEP1

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 870-23-5
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number

$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure:
Pentacarbonyl[1-(ethylthio)pentylidene]tungsten (8a).
Pentacarbonyl(1-ethoxypentylidene)tungsten (7a) (876 mg, 2.00 mmol) in
methanol (5 mL) was added to a stirred suspension of sodium carbonate
(254 mg, 2.40 mmol) in methanol (20 mL) at -40 °C. After ca. 5 min,
ethanethiol (248 mg, 4.00 mmol) in methanol (1 mL) was added dropwise to
the yellow suspension. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at -40 C
and then quenched by addition of a few drops of 85% phosphoric acid to
give a red solution. Water (10 mL) was added and the product was
extracted with n-pentane (3 x 50 mL). The combined organic layers were
dried over MgSO4 and then concentrated under reduced pressure to give a
13:2 mixture of 8a/8a’(880 mg, Rf = 0.6 in n-pentane, red oil).
Pentacarbonyl[2-(cyclohepta-2,4,6-trien-1-yl)-1-(ethylthio)ethylidene]
tungsten (8c).
Pentacarbonyl[2-(cyclohepta-2,4,6-trien-1-yl)-1-ethoxythylidene]tungsten
(7c) (972 mg, 2.00 mmol), sodium carbonate (254 mg, 2.40 mmol), and
ethanethiol (248 mg, 4.00 mmol) were reacted for 6 h at -40 C as
described above to give a 3:1 mixture of 8c/8c’and crystallized from
n-pentane at -20 C (950 mg, 95%, Rf = 0.8 in n-pentane/dichloromethane,
4:1, red crystals, mp 49 C). 8c [8c’]. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 25 C): δ
6.65, 6.25, and 5.33 [6.67, 6.25, and 5.24] (m each, 2:2:2 H; from
H-2to H-7of C7H7), 3.94 [4.04] (q, 3J = 7.8 [7.4] Hz, 2H; 2-H2), 2.99
[3.64] (q, 3J = 7.7 [7.5] Hz, 2H; SCH2), 2.82 [2.56] (m, 1H; 1-H of
C7H7), 1.34 [1.56] (t, 3J = 7.7 [7.5] Hz, 3H; SCH2CH3). 13C NMR (CDCl3,
25 C): δ 334.9 (Cq, C1), 206.3 and 197.6 [Cq, 1:4 C; trans- and cis-CO
of W(CO)5], 131.1, 126.2, and 124.2 [131.1, 125.5, and 124.3] (CH, 2:2:2
C, from C-2to C-7of C7H7), 59.7 [67.0] (CH2, C2), 41.7 [40.5] (CH,
C1), 38.3 [43.0] (SCH2), 11.6 [12.4] (SCH2-CH3). IR (n-pentane): ν˜
2066.1 (50), 1961.3 (60), 1949.9 (100), 1943.0 (90), 1935.6 (80) cm-1
(C≡O). MS (70 eV, EI): m/z (%) 502 [M]+, 446 [M - 2CO]+, 418 [M - 3CO]+,
390 [M - 4CO]+. Anal. Calcd (%) for C16H14O5SW (502.0): C 38.25, H 2.81.
Found: C 38.25, H 2.62.

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 145204-05-3
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 137845-39-7
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 870-23-5
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 951635-85-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16082055
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME454 STEP1

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN

$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. B01C20E23, yield 95%. MW: 521.69
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0

$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. B01C20E30, yield 95%. MW: 491.62
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 870-23-5
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 951635-60-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16089232
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME460 STEP1

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16065943
